newsitem.title: GERMANY: German funds doubled net inflows in 1996 - BVI group.
newsitem.headline: German funds doubled net inflows in 1996 - BVI group.

text.p: German investment funds saw their net inflows more than double to 8.6 billion marks ($5.3 billion) in 1996, amid strong interest in equity-based options, the BVI German Association of Investment Companies said Monday.
In a statement, the BVI said German funds had increased their managed assets by 9.4 percent to 428.8 billion marks over the year, despite net outflows from fixed income funds.

Equity funds attracted many new investors, especially those invested in foreign shares. Overall, net inflows to Germany's 334 share-based funds rose to 2.6 billion marks from 1.1 billion and the total managed volume rose to 65.2 billion marks from 50.9 billion.
However German-based share funds continued to lead the field, with managed assets of 36.9 billion marks.

Bond-based funds, on the other hand, suffered a net outflow of 1.4 billion marks, with the BVI said was partly due to scheduled redemptions of certain investments. Total managed assets rose to 232.5 billion marks from 219.2 billion.
German-invested bond funds attracted net inflows of 2.3 billion marks, reversing a significant sell-off in 1995. ($ = 1.636 German Marks)
